title: How to Disconnect a Mapped Network Drive

steps.title: Open Start .
steps.content: Open Start . Click the Windows logo in the bottom-left corner of the screen.

steps.title: Open File Explorer .
steps.content: Open File Explorer . Click the folder-shaped icon in the bottom-left side of the Start window.

steps.title: Click This PC.
steps.content: Click This PC . It's a computer-shaped item on the left side of the File Explorer window. You may have to scroll up or down here to find it.

steps.title: Click the Computer tab.
steps.content: Click the Computer tab. You'll find this in the upper-left side of the File Explorer window. Clicking it prompts a toolbar to appear at the top of the window.

steps.title: Click Map network drive ▼.
steps.content: Click Map network drive ▼ . It's in the "Network" section of the toolbar. A drop-down menu will appear. Make sure you click the bottom half of this icon and not the top half, as clicking the top half will open a new Network Drive window.

steps.title: Click Disconnect network drive.
steps.content: Click Disconnect network drive . This option is at the bottom of the drop-down menu. Clicking it will prompt a window with a list of all connected network drives to open.

steps.title: Select a network drive.
steps.content: Select a network drive. Click on the drive that you want to disconnect.

steps.title: Click OK.
steps.content: Click OK . It's at the bottom of the window. This will disconnect the drive.

steps.title: Open Finder.
steps.content: Open Finder. Click the blue, face-like app icon in your Mac's Dock.

steps.title: Locate your mapped drive.
steps.content: Locate your mapped drive. On the left side of the Finder window, look for the name of the network drive that you want to disconnect. You'll usually find this below a "Shared" heading.

steps.title: Select the drive.
steps.content: Select the drive. Click the mapped network drive that you want to disconnect.

steps.title: Click Disconnect.
steps.content: Click Disconnect . It's in the main Finder window. Doing so will disconnect your drive from the computer network. If you don't see Disconnect , you can also click the "Eject" button to the right of the network drive.
